Racist, antisemitic AI TikTok clips made with Veo 3, report findsMashable7/3/2025

The Google text-to-video generator produced hateful video clips that went viral.

            <script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","headline":"Racist, antisemitic AI TikTok clips made with Veo 3, report finds","articleBody":"Viral racist and antisemitic TikTok videos appear to be made with Google's new AI video generator Veo 3, according to a new report from Media Matters. The nonprofit research organization found that some of the hateful videos had racked up hundreds of thousands or millions of views. A TikTok spokesperson told Mashable that the platform has firm policies against hate speech, and that it uses comprehensive technologies and moderation processes to implement them. \"We proactively enforce robust rules against hateful speech and behavior and have removed the accounts we identified in the report, many of which were already banned prior to the report publishing,\" the spokesperson told Mashable in an email. One TikTok, labeled \"Average Waffle House in Atlanta,\" featured a restaurant setting overrun by monkeys that throw watermelon and carry buckets of fried chicken. It had been viewed more than 622,000 times when Media Matters took a screenshot of the video. \n        SEE ALSO:\n        \n            Google's Veo 3 AI video generator is unlike anything you've ever seen. The world isn't ready.\n            \n        \n    \nSome of the commenters affirmed the video's racist stereotypes. One person said, \"all their mannerisms…to the T…\"A different TikTok uploaded in mid June, with at least 835,000 views, came with the prompt, \"i asked ai: 'average spirit airlines experience.\" The video featured monkeys as well, climbing all over the plane. Media Matters said the videos it identified ran a maximum of eight seconds, the length of Veo 3's publicly available text-to-video clips. The videos were also labeled \"Veo\" in the corner, or used hashtags, captions, or usernames related to Veo 3 or AI. They also included errors, distortions, and nonsense text common to AI-generated videos. Media Matters published a compilation of the clips it identified to its own YouTube account. Mashable contacted Google for comment on the Media Matters report but hadn't received a response at the time of publication. While Media Matters focused on videos that appeared on TikTok, some of the same objectionable clips have also been posted to YouTube and Instagram.However, the examples Mashable viewed had far less engagement, sometimes receiving only a few hundred likes and a handful of comments, suggesting they have not been as widely viewed as the content that went viral on TikTok before it was removed. In general, videos created with Veo 3 that feature hateful or racist content have become popular on other social media platforms, including Instagram.When Veo 3 was released in late May, Mashable tech editor Timothy Beck Werth described its realism as both \"impressive\" and \"scary.\" Google told Werth that Veo 3's safeguards against misinformation include digital watermarks, and that it employs AI safety guidelines. The AI-generated videos identified by Media Matters included anti-Black stereotypes about criminality, food preferences, and absent fathers. Some featured police encounters with Black people, including one in which a white officer shoots a \"Black one\" from his car. That clip had been viewed more than 14 million times. The clips also portrayed racist imagery against Asian and South Asian people, and depicted antisemitic stereotypes, including Jewish men chasing after a gold coin. One clip, viewed a million times, featured a gaunt man standing in front of a crematorium, vlogging while at a Nazi concentration camp. \"Well everyone is having a great time here,\" the man says. It's unclear if the minute-long video was made with Veo 3. Another style of AI-generated videos seemed to focus on acting violently toward immigrants and protesters defending them. The videos appear to violate Google's hate speech policies. Google's generative AI policy forbids users from generating or distributing content that facilitates hatred or hate speech; harassment and abuse of others, and violence or the incitement of violence. TikTok prohibits hate speech and hateful behavior that \"includes attacking, threatening, dehumanizing or degrading an individual or group based on their protected attributes.\"\n   UPDATE: Jul. 3, 2025, 1:02 p.m. PDT The story was updated to include a statement from             <article id="article" data-autopogo class="mt-8 font-serif editor-content">
                                    <p>Viral racist and antisemitic <a href="https://mashable.com/category/tiktok" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body">TikTok</a> videos appear to be made with <a href="https://mashable.com/category/google" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body">Google's</a> new <a href="https://mashable.com/article/google-veo-3-ai-video" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body">AI video generator Veo 3</a>, <a href="https://www.mediamatters.org/tiktok/racist-ai-generated-videos-are-newest-slop-garnering-millions-views-tiktok" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">according to a new report from Media Matters</a>. </p><p>The nonprofit research organization found that some of the hateful videos had racked up hundreds of thousands or millions of views. </p><p>A TikTok spokesperson told Mashable that the platform has firm policies against hate speech, and that it uses comprehensive technologies and moderation processes to implement them. </p><div id="related-video" class="mx-auto mt-8 mb-12 w-full max-w-3xl font-sans md:mt-12 md:mb-16 text-primary-400">
    <div class="flex flex-row justify-center text-lg text-center md:text-xl">
        <hr class="mx-auto border border-gray-100">
        <strong class="py-4 mx-4 w-full min-w-max text-2xl">You May Also Like</strong>
        <hr class="mx-auto border border-gray-100">
    </div>
    <div class="mx-auto mt-5 max-w-2xl">
        <div id="video-container-6825f5751ad7f3226d4a8257"></div>

<p>"We proactively enforce robust rules against hateful speech and behavior and have removed the accounts we identified in the report, many of which were already banned prior to the report publishing," the spokesperson told Mashable in an email. </p><p>One TikTok, labeled "Average Waffle House in Atlanta," featured a restaurant setting overrun by monkeys that throw watermelon and carry buckets of fried chicken. It had been viewed more than 622,000 times when Media Matters took a <a href="https://www.mediamatters.org/media/4030860" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">screenshot of the video</a>. </p><div class="flex mx-auto mt-8 w-full max-w-3xl font-sans text-lg leading-normal md:text-xl md:leading-7">
        <span class="font-bold text-primary-400">SEE ALSO:</span>
        <a href="/article/google-veo-3-ai-video" class="flex items-center text-secondary-300">
            <span class="ml-1">Google's Veo 3 AI video generator is unlike anything you've ever seen. The world isn't ready.</span>
            <svg class="ml-1 w-4 h-4 font-normal fill-current"><use href="/images/icons/spritemap.svg#sprite-arrow-right-thin"></use></svg>
        </a>
    </div>
<p>Some of the commenters affirmed the video's racist stereotypes. One person <a href="https://www.mediamatters.org/media/4030853" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">said</a>, "all their mannerisms…to the T…"</p><p>A <a href="https://www.mediamatters.org/media/4030861" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">different TikTok</a> uploaded in mid June, with at least 835,000 views, came with the prompt, "i asked ai: 'average spirit airlines experience." The video featured monkeys as well, climbing all over the plane. </p><p>Media Matters said the videos it identified ran a maximum of eight seconds, the length of Veo 3's publicly available text-to-video clips. The videos were also <a href="https://www.mediamatters.org/media/4030969" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">labeled "Veo" in the corner, or used hashtags, captions, or usernames</a> related to Veo 3 or AI. They also included errors, distortions, and nonsense text common to AI-generated videos. </p><p>Media Matters published a compilation of the clips it identified to its <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C16oZPkeg-U" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">own YouTube account</a>. </p><section x-data="window.newsletter()" x-init="init()" class="relative p-8 my-12 mx-auto w-full max-w-3xl border md:p-12 md:my-16 border-secondary-300" data-ga-impression data-ga-category="newsletters" data-ga-module="incontent_nl_signup" data-ga-label="mashablelightspeed">

            Mashable Light Speed
        </div>

<p>Mashable contacted Google for comment on the Media Matters report but hadn't received a response at the time of publication. </p><p>While Media Matters focused on videos that appeared on TikTok, some of the same objectionable clips have also been posted to YouTube and Instagram.</p><p>However, the examples Mashable viewed had far less engagement, sometimes receiving only a few hundred likes and a handful of comments, suggesting they have not been as widely viewed as the content that went viral on TikTok before it was removed. </p><p>In general, videos created with Veo 3 that feature hateful or racist content have become popular on <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/ai-videos-black-women-depicted-as-primates-viral/" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">other social media platforms, including Instagram</a>.</p><p>When Veo 3 was released in late May, Mashable tech editor Timothy Beck Werth described its realism as both "impressive" and "scary." Google told Werth that Veo 3's safeguards against misinformation include digital watermarks, and that it employs AI safety guidelines. </p><p>The AI-generated videos identified by Media Matters included anti-Black stereotypes about criminality, food preferences, and absent fathers. Some featured police encounters with Black people, including one in which a white officer shoots a "Black one" from his car. That clip had been viewed <a href="https://www.mediamatters.org/media/4030870" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">more than 14 million times</a>. </p><div class="related-stories" data-ga-impression data-ga-module="related_stories" data-ga-element="related_stories_link" data-ga-item="title">
    <div class="flex flex-row items-center">
        <hr>
        <div class="px-4 mx-auto mt-0 w-full max-w-3xl font-sans text-2xl font-bold tracking-normal leading-normal text-center whitespace-nowrap shrink">Related Stories</div>
        <hr>
    </div>
    <ul>
                    <li><a href="/article/google-visible-watermark-veo3" data-ga-click data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-action="related_stories" data-ga-position="1">Google introduces small watermark to Veo 3 videos</a></li>
                    <li><a href="/article/tiktok-trump-sale-buyer" data-ga-click data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-action="related_stories" data-ga-position="2">Trump claims a TikTok buyer has been secured</a></li>
                    <li><a href="/article/ai-videos-tiktok-downloading-malware" data-ga-click data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-action="related_stories" data-ga-position="3">Scammers tricked TikTok users into downloading malware with AI videos</a></li>
                    <li><a href="/article/tiktok-shop-deals-for-you-days-prime-day-2025" data-ga-click data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-action="related_stories" data-ga-position="4">Even TikTok is hosting an anti-Prime Day sale</a></li>
            </ul>
</div>
<p>The clips also portrayed racist imagery against Asian and South Asian people, and depicted antisemitic stereotypes, including Jewish men chasing after a gold coin. </p><p>One clip, <a href="https://www.mediamatters.org/media/4030879" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">viewed a million times</a>, featured a gaunt man standing in front of a crematorium, vlogging while at a Nazi concentration camp. "Well everyone is having a great time here," the man says. It's unclear if the minute-long video was made with Veo 3. </p><p>Another style of AI-generated videos seemed to focus on acting violently toward immigrants and protesters defending them. </p><p>The videos appear to violate Google's hate speech policies. <a href="https://policies.google.com/terms/generative-ai/use-policy" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">Google's generative AI policy</a> forbids users from generating or distributing content that facilitates hatred or hate speech; harassment and abuse of others, and violence or the incitement of violence. </p><p><a href="https://www.tiktok.com/safety/en/countering-hate" target="_blank" data-ga-click="1" data-ga-label="$text" data-ga-item="text-link" data-ga-module="content_body" title="(opens in a new window)">TikTok prohibits hate speech and hateful behavior</a> that "includes attacking, threatening, dehumanizing or degrading an individual or group based on their protected attributes."</p><p class="mx-auto">
   <em><strong>UPDATE: Jul. 3, 2025, 1:02 p.m. PDT </strong>The story was updated to include a statement from TikTok.</em>
</p>

readabilityObject.title: Racist, antisemitic AI TikTok clips made with Veo 3, report finds
readabilityObject.content:
The Google text-to-video generator produced hateful video clips that went viral.

 By 

Rebecca Ruiz

Rebecca Ruiz

Senior Reporter

Rebecca Ruiz is a Senior Reporter at Mashable. She frequently covers mental health, digital culture, and technology. Her areas of expertise include suicide prevention, screen use and mental health, parenting, youth well-being, and meditation and mindfulness. Rebecca's experience prior to Mashable includes working as a staff writer, reporter, and editor at NBC News Digital and as a staff writer at Forbes. Rebecca has a B.A. from Sarah Lawrence College and a masters degree from U.C. Berkeley's Graduate School of Journalism.

Read Full Bio

 on July 3, 2025

Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on Flipboard

Hate-filled AI clips on TikTok appear to be made with Google's Veo 3. Credit: NurPhoto / Contributor / Getty Images

Viral racist and antisemitic TikTok videos appear to be made with Google's new AI video generator Veo 3, according to a new report from Media Matters.

The nonprofit research organization found that some of the hateful videos had racked up hundreds of thousands or millions of views.

A TikTok spokesperson told Mashable that the platform has firm policies against hate speech, and that it uses comprehensive technologies and moderation processes to implement them.

"We proactively enforce robust rules against hateful speech and behavior and have removed the accounts we identified in the report, many of which were already banned prior to the report publishing," the spokesperson told Mashable in an email.

One TikTok, labeled "Average Waffle House in Atlanta," featured a restaurant setting overrun by monkeys that throw watermelon and carry buckets of fried chicken. It had been viewed more than 622,000 times when Media Matters took a screenshot of the video.

Some of the commenters affirmed the video's racist stereotypes. One person said, "all their mannerismsto the T"

A different TikTok uploaded in mid June, with at least 835,000 views, came with the prompt, "i asked ai: 'average spirit airlines experience." The video featured monkeys as well, climbing all over the plane.

Media Matters said the videos it identified ran a maximum of eight seconds, the length of Veo 3's publicly available text-to-video clips. The videos were also labeled "Veo" in the corner, or used hashtags, captions, or usernames related to Veo 3 or AI. They also included errors, distortions, and nonsense text common to AI-generated videos.

Media Matters published a compilation of the clips it identified to its own YouTube account.

Mashable Light Speed

Mashable contacted Google for comment on the Media Matters report but hadn't received a response at the time of publication.

While Media Matters focused on videos that appeared on TikTok, some of the same objectionable clips have also been posted to YouTube and Instagram.

However, the examples Mashable viewed had far less engagement, sometimes receiving only a few hundred likes and a handful of comments, suggesting they have not been as widely viewed as the content that went viral on TikTok before it was removed.

In general, videos created with Veo 3 that feature hateful or racist content have become popular on other social media platforms, including Instagram.

When Veo 3 was released in late May, Mashable tech editor Timothy Beck Werth described its realism as both "impressive" and "scary." Google told Werth that Veo 3's safeguards against misinformation include digital watermarks, and that it employs AI safety guidelines.

The AI-generated videos identified by Media Matters included anti-Black stereotypes about criminality, food preferences, and absent fathers. Some featured police encounters with Black people, including one in which a white officer shoots a "Black one" from his car. That clip had been viewed more than 14 million times.

The clips also portrayed racist imagery against Asian and South Asian people, and depicted antisemitic stereotypes, including Jewish men chasing after a gold coin.

One clip, viewed a million times, featured a gaunt man standing in front of a crematorium, vlogging while at a Nazi concentration camp. "Well everyone is having a great time here," the man says. It's unclear if the minute-long video was made with Veo 3.

Another style of AI-generated videos seemed to focus on acting violently toward immigrants and protesters defending them.

The videos appear to violate Google's hate speech policies. Google's generative AI policy forbids users from generating or distributing content that facilitates hatred or hate speech; harassment and abuse of others, and violence or the incitement of violence.

TikTok prohibits hate speech and hateful behavior that "includes attacking, threatening, dehumanizing or degrading an individual or group based on their protected attributes."

UPDATE: Jul. 3, 2025, 1:02 p.m. PDT The story was updated to include a statement from TikTok.

Rebecca Ruiz is a Senior Reporter at Mashable. She frequently covers mental health, digital culture, and technology. Her areas of expertise include suicide prevention, screen use and mental health, parenting, youth well-being, and meditation and mindfulness. Rebecca's experience prior to Mashable includes working as a staff writer, reporter, and editor at NBC News Digital and as a staff writer at Forbes. Rebecca has a B.A. from Sarah Lawrence College and a masters degree from U.C. Berkeley's Graduate School of Journalism.

One person said, "all their mannerismsto the T"A different TikTok uploaded in mid June, with at least 835,000 views, came with the prompt, "i asked ai: 'average spirit airlines experience." The video featured monkeys as well, climbing all over the plane. Media Matters said the videos it identified ran a maximum of eight seconds, the length of Veo 3's publicly available text-to-video clips. The videos were also labeled "Veo" in the corner, or used hashtags, captions, or usernames related to Veo 3 or AI. They also included errors, distortions, and nonsense text common to AI-generated videos. Media Matters published a compilation of the clips it identified to its own YouTube account. 
        
            Mashable Light Speed
        
        
        
    
Mashable contacted Google for comment on the Media Matters report but hadn't received a response at the time of publication. While Media Matters focused on videos that appeared on TikTok, some of the same objectionable clips have also been posted to YouTube and Instagram.However, the examples Mashable viewed had far less engagement, sometimes receiving only a few hundred likes and a handful of comments, suggesting they have not been as widely viewed as the content that went viral on TikTok before it was removed. In general, videos created with Veo 3 that feature hateful or racist content have become popular on other social media platforms, including Instagram.When Veo 3 was released in late May, Mashable tech editor Timothy Beck Werth described its realism as both "impressive" and "scary." Google told Werth that Veo 3's safeguards against misinformation include digital watermarks, and that it employs AI safety guidelines. The AI-generated videos identified by Media Matters included anti-Black stereotypes about criminality, food preferences, and absent fathers. Some featured police encounters with Black people, including one in which a white officer shoots a "Black one" from his car. That clip had been viewed more than 14 million times. 
The clips also portrayed racist imagery against Asian and South Asian people, and depicted antisemitic stereotypes, including Jewish men chasing after a gold coin. One clip, viewed a million times, featured a gaunt man standing in front of a crematorium, vlogging while at a Nazi concentration camp. "Well everyone is having a great time here," the man says. It's unclear if the minute-long video was made with Veo 3. Another style of AI-generated videos seemed to focus on acting violently toward immigrants and protesters defending them. The videos appear to violate Google's hate speech policies. Google's generative AI policy forbids users from generating or distributing content that facilitates hatred or hate speech; harassment and abuse of others, and violence or the incitement of violence. TikTok prohibits hate speech and hateful behavior that "includes attacking, threatening, dehumanizing or degrading an individual or group based on their protected attributes."
   UPDATE: Jul. 3, 2025, 1:02 p.m. PDT The story was updated to include a statement from TikTok.


                                        
                    
    
    
    
            
            
                    
                
            Rebecca Ruiz is a Senior Reporter at Mashable. She frequently covers mental health, digital culture, and technology. Her areas of expertise include suicide prevention, screen use and mental health, parenting, youth well-being, and meditation and mindfulness. Rebecca's experience prior to Mashable includes working as a staff writer, reporter, and editor at NBC News Digital and as a staff writer at Forbes. Rebecca has a B.A. from Sarah Lawrence College and a masters degree from U.C. Berkeley's Graduate School of Journalism.

The nonprofit research organization found that some of the hateful videos had racked up hundreds of thousands or millions of views. A TikTok spokesperson told Mashable that the platform has firm policies against hate speech, and that it uses comprehensive technologies and moderation processes to implement them. "We proactively enforce robust rules against hateful speech and behavior and have removed the accounts we identified in the report, many of which were already banned prior to the report publishing," the spokesperson told Mashable in an email. One TikTok, labeled "Average Waffle House in Atlanta," featured a restaurant setting overrun by monkeys that throw watermelon and carry buckets of fried chicken.
